metadata.case_name: Sashi Mohan Debnath & Ors. v. State

facts.text: Eight accused tried in Court of Session before Additional Sessions Judge, 24 Parganas at Alipore in Sessions Trial No. 2 of May 1954, charged under ss. 147 and 304/149 IPC; accused Nos. 1,2,3,6 further charged under s. 201 IPC.
Trial Judge delivered charge to jury favourable to accused.
Jury returned unanimous verdict of not guilty under s. 304/149 IPC, which trial Judge accepted and acquitted all accused of this offence.

Jury returned unanimous verdict of guilty under ss. 147 and 201 IPC against charged accused; trial Judge disagreed and made reference under s. 307 CrPC to Calcutta High Court on June 7, 1954, opining accused not guilty of these offences.

Calcutta High Court in Reference No. 6 of 1954 dated July 21, 1954 accepted reference in part: convicted Sashi Mohan Debnath, Rajendra Debnath, Sudhanshu Kumar Debnath, Dinesh Chandra Debnath and Bonomali Das under s. 147 IPC to 1 year RI each; Sashi Mohan Debnath and Rajendra Debnath under s. 201 IPC to 3 years RI (concurrent); acquitted Manindra Debnath, Gouranga Debnath under s. 147, Manindra and Rohini Kumar Debnath under s. 201.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave by Sashi Mohan Debnath, Rajendra Debnath, Sudhanshu Kumar Debnath and Bonomali Das.

On September 12, 1956, Supreme Court ordered notices to accused Nos. 3,6,8 (Manindra Debnath, Rohini Kumar Debnath, Gouranga Debnath); served on Manindra and Gouranga; Rohini untraceable; none appeared.
Reference letter dated June 7, 1954; over three years old by time of SC judgment.
Judge who made reference has retired; successor may not be able to deal with case.

legal_issues.text: Whether the reference made to the Calcutta High Court by the Additional Sessions Judge under s. 307 CrPC was competent, and if not, whether the High Court acted with jurisdiction in convicting or acquitting any of the accused.

petitioner_arguments.text: Reference under s. 307 CrPC incompetent as it was only part of the case (after accepting jury verdict and acquitting on s. 304/149 IPC); recording judgment on some charges contravenes s. 307(2); cited Calcutta and Allahabad HC decisions supporting HC can deal with partial reference.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 307 CrPC; King Emperor v. Ananda Charan Ray; Emperor v. Jagmohan; Emperor v. Muktar

respondent_arguments.text: No submissions made on facts; supported view that HC could deal with reference even if partial, based on certain HC decisions.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme of CrPC ss. 306-307 requires reference of whole case tried by jury, not part; judge cannot record judgment on any charge if disagreeing and referring, per s. 307(2); partial reference incompetent as condition precedent for HC powers under s. 307(3).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words 'the case' in s. 307 refer to whole case under s. 306; amendments in 1923 and 1955 confirm this.

court_reasoning.text: By acquitting on s. 304/149, trial judge prevented HC from considering entire evidence; Patna HC view correct (Hazari Lal, Ramjanam Tewari); Calcutta HC in Bishnu Chandra Das agreed reference incompetent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: HC cannot exercise s. 307(3) powers on incompetent partial reference.

court_reasoning.text: Rejected arguments based on Ananda Charan Ray (which rejected partial reference), Nawal Behari (incompetent), Jagmohan (erroneous), Muktar (defect fatal).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reference incompetent; HC should reject and remit.

holdings.text: Reference under s. 307 CrPC must be of whole case against accused, not part; partial reference incompetent; HC lacks jurisdiction to convict/acquit thereon.

precedents_cited.relevance: Reference under s. 307 must be whole case, not part; partial incompetent.
Reaffirmed whole case must be referred.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Emperor v. Bishnu Chandra Das
precedents_cited.relevance: Sessions Judge disabled valid reference by accepting jury on some charges.

precedents_cited.case_name: King Emperor v. Ananda Charan Ray
precedents_cited.relevance: Rejected partial reference as tying hands of HC; directed acquittal.
Must refer whole case; but HC proceeded erroneously.
Erroneous view that HC can consider whole case despite partial reference.
Defect in partial reference fatal; unsustainable.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Charges framed; jury verdicts on these.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference procedure for jury trials; must refer whole case; amendments 1923, 1955 analyzed.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; held reference under s. 307 CrPC incompetent as partial (after acquittal on s. 304/149); due to lapse of time since 1953 occurrence, retirement of trial judge, not remanded to Sessions Court.

key_quotes.text: "the case to be submitted to the High Court is the whole case against the accused and not a part of it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on s. 307 CrPC interpretation.

key_quotes.text: "a reference made under s. 307 must be of the whole case against the accused and not a part of it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms Patna HC view adopted by SC.

key_quotes.text: "We emphasise the absolute need for making a competent reference under s. 307 of the Code"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Guidance to lower courts on procedure.
